question: What should the missionary do if a student with a gathering responsibility isn't able to participate?
human_answer:
Missionaries will be expected to take the lead of the gathering and deliver the week's assigned lesson to the best of their ability if the lead student isn't available.

Here are some possible contigency ideas:
Assign two lead students to work together each week depending on your group size.

Before each gathering, study the gathering agenda and review the assignments on Canvas to have a better understanding of the student's expectations for the week.

Contact the lead student several days before the gathering to confirm their attendance and encourage them to review the gathering agenda with time.

Prompt students to notify you with time if they will be unable to attend the gathering and complete their duties as lead student.

Work with the observing student and the other students in the group to explain specific assignments and challenging topics to the rest of the group.
ai_answer:
If a student with a gathering responsibility isn't able to participate, the missionary should consider a few steps to address the situation effectively. First, the missionary could assign two lead students to work together each week, especially if the group size allows for it [^4]. Additionally, before each gathering, the missionary should communicate with the lead student several days in advance to confirm their attendance and ensure they are prepared for their responsibilities [^4]. If the lead student notifies the missionary that they cannot attend, the missionary should work with the observing student and other group members to ensure that specific assignments and challenging topics are still addressed during the gathering [^4].

Moreover, if the student needs to move to a different gathering due to their inability to participate in the current one, the missionary should contact their District Leader, Zone Leader, or ACM to facilitate the transfer process [^5]. The missionary will need to provide specific information such as the student's ID number, name, current gathering details, and the day and time the student needs for the new gathering [^5]. This process may involve transferring the student to a different area, location, or within the same location, depending on the circumstances [^5].

By following these steps, the missionary can effectively manage situations where a student with a gathering responsibility is unable to participate, ensuring that the gathering runs smoothly and that the student's needs are appropriately addressed [^4] [^5].

question: What should the missionary do to prepare for a gathering?
human_answer:
All your needed resources are found in the Gathering Resources section of the Missionary Services website. Be familiar with the concept of a lead student and lead observer. Understand how to use any technology needed to support the students.

1.     Read the Gathering Procedures—An outline of what to do before, during, and after a gathering along with tips about how to encourage students outside of the gathering.
2.     Read the Gathering Guide—A valuable tool for everyone at the gathering to help make it a great experience.
3.     Learn about the Observation Feedback Sheet—A tool to help you and the observing student provide feedback to the lead student after the gathering is complete.
4.     Find lead students for each gathering and assign them in the Lead Student Sign-up Sheet—Use these sign-up sheets at the beginning of each term to allow students to sign up for an opportunity to act as the lead student.
5.     Study the gathering agendas. They are a weekly plan to guide the lead student through the discussion at the gatherings. Gathering agendas are found in your Gathering Resources section on the Missionary Services website.
ai_answer:
To prepare for a gathering, a missionary should follow several key steps based on the provided documents:

1. Familiarize themselves with the concept of a lead student and lead observer [^2].
2. Understand how to use any necessary technology to support the students during the gathering [^2].
3. Learn about the Observation Feedback Sheet, a tool used to provide feedback to the lead student after the gathering [^2].
4. Find lead students for each gathering and assign them using the Lead Student Sign-up Sheet [^2].
5. Study the gathering agendas, which are weekly plans to guide the lead student through the discussion at the gatherings [^2].
6. Ensure the building is open and the room is prepared for an in-person gathering or that the computer, microphone, and camera are ready for a virtual gathering [^1].
7. Assist the lead student with setup at the beginning of the gathering [^1].
8. Greet students by name as they arrive to create a welcoming atmosphere [^1].

By following these steps, the missionary can effectively prepare for a successful gathering and provide valuable support to the students.

question: How to get class members to be lead and observing student or give the devotional?
human_answer:
Leadership development is an integral part of a BYU-Idaho
education. And in Pathway, a method has been developed that
provides each student the opportunity to develop valuable
leadership skills.
During Pathway, every student will serve as a “lead student.”
As the lead student, you will come to the weekly Pathway
gathering prepared to facilitate the assigned lesson. All students
are expected to come to class prepared, having insights and
questions and a willingness to contribute in class activities.

Rather than a lecture-based educational process, students have the opportunity to lead students in the Gathering.  Students are directed to engage fellow classmates in discussions and learning activities, with the goal of engaging everyone.

Students are not required to participate as a lead student; however, it is strongly encouraged. Any questions regarding being a lead student should be directed to your site missionaries.

Lead Student Tools
To access lead student tools (including the virtual gathering group), you can do the following:
Sign in to the course on Canvas
Click "Modules"
Scroll down and click ""Lead Student Tools"" at the bottom of the page
ai_answer:
Based on the available information, to get class members to be lead and observing students or give the devotional in a BYU Pathway class, you can follow these steps:

1. **Explain the Roles**: Make sure to explain the roles of lead and observing students to all class members [^4]. This will help them understand what is expected of each role and how they can contribute to the gathering.

2. **Create a Sign-Up List**: Create a sign-up list to select lead learners for the gatherings starting from Week 3 [^5]. This allows class members to volunteer for these roles and participate actively in the Pathway program.

3. **Assign Roles**: Assign lead and observing students for specific weeks during the first gathering [^4]. By assigning these roles in advance, you can ensure that class members are prepared and know their responsibilities.

4. **Encourage Participation**: Encourage class members to volunteer for these roles by praying about who to invite to be a lead learner [^5]. Some individuals may need a private invitation, so be mindful of their comfort levels and encourage them to participate.

5. **Provide Resources and Support**: Offer resources, encouragement, and help to each lead student [^4]. Supporting class members in these roles will help them feel more confident and prepared to fulfill their responsibilities.

By following these steps, you can effectively involve class members as lead and observing students or in giving devotionals in BYU Pathway classes.

question: How do I find the weekly gathering agenda?
human_answer:
Gathering agendas are found in your weekly Gathering Resources also known as Missionary Guides.

Gathering agendas can be found on the Missionary Services website.
1.     Go to the navigation bar under Gathering Resources.
2.     In the dropdown menu, select the program such as EnglishConnect 3, PC 101, PC 102, or PC 103.
3.     Click the link for the current week in the flyout menu to see that week’s content.
4.     The gathering agenda links are found near the top of the page in the blue boxes.
ai_answer:
To find the weekly gathering agenda, you can follow these steps based on the provided documents:

1. Go to the Missionary Services website and navigate to the *Gathering Resources* section [^1].
2. In the dropdown menu, select the program you are interested in, such as EnglishConnect 3, PC 101, PC 102, or PC 103.
3. Click on the link for the current week in the flyout menu to access that week's content.
4. Look for the gathering agenda links near the top of the page in the blue boxes [^1].

By following these steps, you should be able to easily find the weekly gathering agenda for your specific program on the Missionary Services website [^1].

question: How can a student sign into their student portal?
human_answer: Students can sign into their student portal by going to the PathwayConnect website, byupathway.edu.  Click on Sign In at the top right-hand corner of the page.  Choose Sign In  under PathwayConnect.  Sign in to the student's church account.

4. Alternatively, students can go directly to byupathway.edu/sign-in to sign in to their portal [^5].

These steps will allow students to successfully sign into their student portal on the BYU Pathway website.

question: What are the most absences a student can have and still pass PC101?
human_answer:
Absences will impact a student’s grade depending on how many a student misses. There is no specific number of absences a student can miss to still pass PC 101.

Missing gathering impacts students’ grades. The more gatherings that students miss, the more impact they will see on their grades. You may choose to reach out to students who have missed several gatherings or who appear to be falsely reporting their attendance if prompted by the Spirit.
ai_answer: The number of absences a student can have and still pass PC101 is not specifically defined by a set number of absences. Instead, it depends on the individual circumstances of the student. The decision is influenced by factors such as the student's overall participation, engagement, and the guidance of the Spirit [^1]. The PathwayConnect program values honesty and integrity, so it is essential for students to attend gatherings regularly and truthfully report their attendance [^1]. If a student has missed several gatherings or is suspected of falsely reporting their attendance, they may face consequences as prompted by the Spirit [^1].

question: How do I create a WhatsApp group?
human_answer: Missionaries can create a WhatsApp group with up to 1024 members.
ai_answer:
To create a WhatsApp group, you can follow these steps:
1. Click on **New group** in WhatsApp [^1].
2. Search and select contacts to add to the group.
3. Enter a group subject, which will be the name visible to all members [^1].
4. Optionally, you can add an emoji to the group subject [^1].
5. You can also add a group icon by clicking on the relevant option [^1].
6. Choose to **Take photo**, **Upload photo**, or use **Emoji & sticker** for the group icon [^1].
7. Once set, the icon will appear next to the group in your chats list [^1].
8. Click **Create** when you're finished [^1].

This is the answer based on the source [^1].

question: How to avoid WhatsApp cancelling my account for spam?
human_answer:
Best practices
Communicate with known contacts: Only send messages to those who have contacted you first or have requested you contact them on WhatsApp. It's best to give contacts your phone number so they can message you first.
Ask for permission and respect boundaries: You should get permission from contacts before you add them to a group. If you add someone to a group and they remove themselves, honor their decision.
Use group controls: We've created an admin only message setting for WhatsApp groups. If you're an admin, you can decide if all members or only group admins can send messages within the group. Using this feature can help cut down unwanted messages in groups. Learn how to change group admin settings.
Think twice before forwarding messages: We created a label for all forwarded messages and limit the number of times you can forward messages as a way to encourage users to reconsider before sharing. If you aren’t sure whether something’s true or don’t know who wrote the message, we don’t recommend forwarding it. Learn more about preventing the spread of misinformation in this article.
ai_answer:
To avoid WhatsApp canceling your account for spam, you should adhere to specific guidelines outlined by WhatsApp to ensure responsible use of the platform [^1]. Here are some key practices to prevent your account from being banned for spamming:
1. **Avoid sending unwanted messages**: If a contact asks you to stop messaging them, remove the contact from your address book and refrain from contacting them again [^1].
2. **Do not engage in automated or bulk messaging**: Refrain from sending bulk messages, auto-messages, or auto-dialing using WhatsApp as this violates WhatsApp's policies and may lead to an account ban [^1].
3. **Use contact lists ethically**: Only message individuals who have consented to receive messages from you and refrain from using data obtained from unauthorized sources to message users or add them to groups [^1].
4. **Limit the use of broadcast lists**: Excessive use of broadcast messages may lead to users reporting your messages, which can result in an account ban [^1].
5. **Avoid harvesting personal information**: Do not extract information from WhatsApp users in an automated manner for unauthorized purposes, as this violates WhatsApp's Terms of Service [^1].
6. **Comply with WhatsApp's Terms of Service**: Ensure that your behavior on WhatsApp aligns with the platform's Terms of Service, avoiding any illegal, threatening, or offensive activities [^1].

By following these guidelines and using WhatsApp responsibly, you can reduce the risk of your account being banned for spamming activities [^1].

Also, don't create accounts or groups in unauthorized or automated ways, or use modified versions of WhatsApp. For more information on how WhatsApp prevents abuse of automated and bulk messaging, you can read this white paper. * **Using contact lists that aren’t yours**: Don’t share phone numbers without consent or use data obtained from illicit sources to message users on WhatsApp or add them to groups. * **Over-using broadcast lists**: Messages sent using a broadcast list will only be received when users have added your phone number to their contact list. The acquisition of information from users in this way, including phone numbers, user profile pictures, and statuses from WhatsApp violates our Terms of Service. * **Violating our Terms of Service**: As a reminder, our Terms of Service prohibit, amongst other things, publishing falsehoods and engaging in illegal, threatening, intimidating, hateful, and racially or ethnically offensive behavior. question: What should I do if WhatsApp cancels me for spam?
human_answer: If you think your account was banned by mistake, tap Request a review in the app and we'll look into your case. We'll get back to you as soon as we complete our review. We only review one phone number per appeal.
ai_answer:
If WhatsApp cancels your account for spam, it means your account has violated their Terms of Service by engaging in activities like spamming, scams, or behaviors that endanger the safety of WhatsApp users [^1]. To prevent this, it is crucial to use WhatsApp responsibly and avoid actions that could lead to a ban [^3]. If your account is banned, you will see a message stating, "This account is not allowed to use WhatsApp" when you try to open the app [^1].

To address this issue, you should carefully review the "Acceptable Use of Our Services” section in WhatsApp's Terms of Service to understand the appropriate uses of the platform and activities that are prohibited [^1]. It is essential to adhere to these guidelines to ensure compliance and avoid future bans.

If you believe your account was banned unfairly or mistakenly, you can reach out to WhatsApp support for assistance. You can contact WhatsApp support via email, and they will respond to you from email addresses ending in @support.whatsapp.com [^6]. When contacting support, you can provide additional information about your issue, such as phone network information, device details, and WhatsApp app information, to help them understand and resolve the problem [^6].

By following these steps and using WhatsApp responsibly, you can work towards resolving issues related to spam and ensure a positive experience on the platform.

question: How to set up study groups for introductory certificates
human_answer:
Study groups can be helpful to students who are taking an introductory certificate in PC 103. It is not required that you set up these groups. Connect with your area leaders for approval and  assistance to coordinate these groups.

1.     First, select the best method for students for your area to meet online or in-person. You may consider creating a WhatsApp group. Groups can be as large as 1024 members.
2.     Connect with your zone or district leader to identify the types certificates being taken in your zone or district.
3.     Communicate to students that a study group will be available.
4.     Gain a student’s permission before adding him or her to a group (online or in-person).
5.     Let the students lead the groups. You should avoid attending and assisting in study groups as a missionary.
ai_answer:
Setting up study groups for introductory certificates involves several steps to ensure effective collaboration among students. Here is a detailed guide based on the provided information:

1. **Identify Certificate Types**: Connect with your zone or district leader to identify the types of certificates being pursued in your area [^1].
   
2. **Communicate with Students**: Inform students that a study group will be available for their certificate program [^1].
   
3. **Obtain Student Permission**: Before adding students to a study group, make sure to gain their permission, whether the group is online or in-person [^1].
   
4. **Let Students Lead**: Encourage students to take the lead in the study groups. As a missionary, it is advised to avoid attending and assisting in study groups actively [^1].

By following these steps, you can effectively set up study groups for introductory certificates, fostering a collaborative and supportive learning environment for PathwayConnect students.

You may be asked by a student about certificates and course options. Remember, it is not your role to give strong support for one choice over another. You help the student consider the positive and negative aspects of each choice.

question: How to send individual messages to students with WhatsApp?
human_answer:
To send a message through WhatsApp, you will need a cell phone number, the WhatsApp app on your smartphone, and a WhatsApp account. Accounts are free.

1.     Go to the Google Play Store or Apple App Store and download the WhatsApp app to your smartphone.
2.     Verify and register your phone number.
3.     Add your student or learner contact information to your account.
4.     Click the Chats icon.
5.     Search for the person you want to text in the search bar and select their name.
6.     Type your message and click the send button.

question: How do I add students to a WhatsApp group?
human_answer: To add students to your WhatsApp group, first get their permission.
ai_answer:
To add students to a WhatsApp group, you can follow these steps based on the information provided in the knowledge base:

1. Open the WhatsApp group chat and tap on the group subject [^2].
2. Alternatively, you can swipe the group to the left in the Chats tab and tap on More > Group Info [^3].
3. Tap on "Add Members" or "Invite to Group via Link" [^3].
4. Search for or select the contacts (students) you want to add to the group [^2].
5. Tap on "Add" or "Add" to finalize adding the selected contacts to the group [^3].

Remember that if the group has "Approve New Members" turned on and there are pending requests to join the group, an admin can review these requests [^2].

question: If I have questions about Whatsapp, is there a customer service I can talk with?
human_answer:
When you contact WhatsApp Support they may communicate with you over email or in a chat thread.
When you connect with WhatsApp Support over email, we will get back to you with an email response. WhatsApp Support will only contact you from email addresses ending in @support.whatsapp.com.
When you connect with WhatsApp Support in a chat thread, we will only message you from our official WhatsApp Support account, which is marked with the verified badge and the Official Support Account label.
You might also interact with artificial intelligence (AI), when you contact WhatsApp Support. Responses generated by AI are labeled with AIAI sparkle in the message bubble. At times, messages generated by AI may be inaccurate or inappropriate. We recommend checking the Help Center to further assist in resolving your issue.
If you receive a message claiming to be WhatsApp Support, but doesn’t have the verified badge or the Official Support Account label, this is likely a scam. Please do not reply and please report or block this number.
There are certain pieces of information WhatsApp will never ask you. These include: sensitive personal information, your full name, PIN, or payment details.
ai_answer: If you have questions about WhatsApp, you can contact WhatsApp Support for assistance [^1]. They can help you with various issues related to using the application, such as setting up an account, troubleshooting technical problems, or understanding specific features. WhatsApp Support can be reached through a chat thread within the app or via email [^1]. It's important to note that when you interact with WhatsApp Support, you may also encounter responses generated by artificial intelligence (AI) [^1]. In case you receive a message from someone claiming to be WhatsApp Support but without the verified badge or the Official Support Account label, it is likely a scam, and you should not reply to it. Instead, promptly report and/or block the number [^1].

question: How do I use breakout rooms?
human_answer:
In each Gathering Agenda, when the Gathering Agenda asks that students to meet in small groups, use Breakout Rooms.

Missionaries should learn Breakout Room Basics for Gatherings.
ai_answer:
To use breakout rooms in Zoom, you can follow these steps based on the provided information:

1. Click on the breakout room option on the bottom menu of your Zoom window to access the room control panel [^1].
2. Choose the number of breakout rooms you want to create and decide whether to assign groups automatically or manually [^1].
3. Click "Create" to generate and configure the breakout rooms [^1].
4. If needed, you can adjust the breakout room assignments by clicking "Move To" or "Exchange" next to each participant [^1].
5. Configure the breakout room settings by clicking the gear symbol in the lower left corner. In the settings window, you can allow participants to return to the main room, move students automatically into their breakout rooms, set the time needed for the breakout rooms, and set a countdown timer to notify students when they will return to the main session [^1].

These steps will help you effectively utilize breakout rooms in Zoom for your gatherings or meetings.

Click **Share** in your Zoom room menu bar while your breakout rooms popup menu is open. - The breakout rooms must be in progress before sharing your screen. 2. In the Share window, click **Layout and Options** to view more share options. 3. Check the box for **Share to breakout rooms**. - Check the box for **Share sound** if you are going to be sharing audio. - Avoid optimizing video if your group has low internet bandwidth. 4. Choose the screen(s) you want to share and select the blue **Share** button. 5. A popup will display informing you that your screen will be shared with the breakout rooms. - It states that audio will not be shared. Your audio will be shared if you selected **Share Sound** in the previous screen. 6. Select the blue **Share** button in the popup to begin sharing your screen. 7. Your screen sharing session will end if you join one of the breakout rooms. - You must remain in the main session to continue sharing your screen with all the breakout rooms. 8. Select the red **Stop share** button beneath the black menu bar when you are ready to stop sharing.

question: Where do I find my zoom link?
human_answer: Missionaries can find their Zoom Link by openning their zoom meeting room and clicking on the green shield at the top of the Zoom meeting window.
ai_answer:
To find your Zoom meeting link, you can follow these steps:
1. Open your personal Zoom meeting room.
2. Click the green **Information Shield** in the top-right corner of the screen.
3. Select **Copy Link** to copy it to your computer's clipboard.
4. Go into your email and paste the link into the content area of a new email.
5. Add anyone who needs the link in the **To** section and send the email. 

These steps will help you easily locate and share your Zoom meeting link [^1].

Select View in the upper right corner to display the available viewing options. - These options allow you to see only the speaker, see the whole group, or see multiple speakers simultaneously. 3. Click the audio icon in the lower left corner of the screen to mute or unmute your microphone. 5. To view the list of students in the meeting, click the participants icon in the menu bar at the bottom of your screen. 9. You can mute individuals by hovering over their name and clicking the blue Mute button in the participants menu. 10. You can also mute all participants by clicking the Mute All button at the bottom of the window. - This can help reduce background noise if some participants have their microphones on.

question: How do I use zoom to take attendance?
human_answer:
Your area leaders may ask that you track attendance for your gathering. Attendance is tracked in the Reports section of your Zoom account when logged in to the Zoom website.
 
EnglishConnect 3 missionaries will find this helpful as they are asked to give participation certificates to each learner who has consistently attended. Certificates are awarded at the end of the EnglishConnect 3 term. Missionaries assigned to PathwayConnect gatherings might check attendance to know whom to give extra support.

You can download a Zoom report showing which individuals attended each gathering.
1.     Sign in to the Zoom web portal.
2.     In the navigation menu, click Reports.
3.     Click the Usage Reports tab.
4.     Click Usage.
5.     At the top, use the following functionalities to sort the data by meeting:
·      Search by time range: Select a time range (within a month) using the From and To fields, then click Search.
·      Search by meeting ID: Enter the meeting ID in the search box, then click Search.
6.     Locate your meeting, then click the participant count (number) under the Participants Source column. A list of internal and external meeting participants will appear. This will show you a list of meeting participants, including join and leave times.
7.     Export the attendee list as a CSV file.
 
Resources
·      Zoom Support: How to obtain a meeting attendance report
ai_answer:
To use Zoom to take attendance, you can follow these steps:
1. Log in to your Zoom account on the Zoom website [^1].
2. Go to the "Reports" section of your Zoom account to track attendance [^1].
3. Search for the meeting ID of the gathering you want to track attendance for [^1].
4. Locate the meeting and click on the participant count under the "Participants Source" column to see a list of meeting participants with join and leave times [^1].
5. You can then export the attendee list as a CSV file for record-keeping [^1].

These steps will help you effectively track attendance for your Zoom meetings.

question: How does a student find their gathering zoom link?
human_answer:
Students can find the link to their Gathering in their  BYU-Pathway Student Portal (sign in at https://www.byupathway.org,) 

Click "My Gathering" to find the location of your gathering.  The details of a student's gathering and a link to "Join Virtual Gathering" are included under "My Gathering."

If a student is on a mobile device, they can find these options by going to the triple line icon.
ai_answer: To find their gathering Zoom link, a student can access it through their BYU-Pathway Portal. They need to log in to the student portal and navigate to the "My Gathering" section [^1]. Within the "My Gathering" section, students can find essential information about their gathering, including the Zoom link for virtual gatherings [^3]. By clicking on the provided Zoom link, students will be directed to their gathering's Zoom room, where they can join the virtual meeting [^1]. Additionally, if students encounter any difficulties or need further assistance, they can reach out to their Peer Mentor for help [^6].

question: Should missionaries send the gathering zoom link with reminder for the gathering?
human_answer: Students should be directed to join their gathering each week from the link in their student portal.  This eliminates confusion and simplifies things for the student.
ai_answer: Yes, missionaries should send the gathering Zoom link as a reminder for the gathering [^1]. This helps ensure that students have easy access to the virtual meeting location and can join the gathering promptly. Sending the link ahead of time allows students to prepare and familiarize themselves with the technology before the gathering begins [^7]. It is recommended to send the link 24 hours ahead of time and then again an hour or two before the gathering [^1]. Additionally, missionaries should include important details such as the time, place or link, and any preparations students need to make for the gathering [^1].

question: How do I get into Zoom?
human_answer: Open your Zoom Desktop App.  If you are not already signed in, Sign into your Zoom Account.  Then click on the orange New Meeting Button.
ai_answer:
To access Zoom, you can follow these steps based on the provided documents:

1. **Activate Your Zoom Account**: If you are a BYU-Pathway student, you will receive an activation email from Zoom at your BYU-Pathway email address. Check your spam folder if you don't see the email. Click on the blue box titled **Activate Your Zoom Account** in the email to start the activation process [^7].

2. **Login to the Zoom Website**: After activating your account, go to byupathway.zoom.us in your internet browser. Click on **Sign In** and enter the email address and password you created during the activation process. This will log you into your Zoom account [^9].

3. **Join a Zoom Meeting**: Once you are logged in, to join a Zoom meeting, you will need a meeting link or ID. If you have a passcode-embedded link, click on it to join the meeting. If the link is not clickable, you can copy and paste it into your browser's address bar. This will take you to the meeting on byupathway.zoom.us [^3].

By following these steps, you can successfully access Zoom for your BYU-Pathway gatherings and meetings.

Learn The Basic Features Of Zoom / Basic Features 1. Select the information icon in the upper right corner of the screen to view information about the meeting. - This includes the meeting ID, the host of the meeting, and the meeting URL. 2. Select View in the upper right corner to display the available viewing options. - These options allow you to see only the speaker, see the whole group, or see multiple speakers simultaneously. 3. To see all students during the meeting, select Gallery from the view options. - This is the preferred setting for gathering meetings. - In this view, the speaker is highlighted. 4. Click the audio icon in the lower left corner of the screen to mute or unmute your microphone. 5. Click the arrow to the right of the audio icon to open audio options. - To access additional audio settings, select Audio Settings listed at the bottom of the popup. 6. To turn your video on and off, select the video icon in the lower-left corner of the screen. - Encourage students to have their video turned on during meetings whenever possible. 7. Click the arrow to the right of the video icon to open video options. - To access additional audio settings, select Video Settings listed at the bottom of the popup. 8. To view the list of students in the meeting, click the participants icon in the menu bar at the bottom of your screen. 9. You can mute individuals by hovering over their name and clicking the blue Mute button in the participants menu. 10. You can also mute all participants by clicking the Mute All button at the bottom of the window. - This can help reduce background noise if some participants have their microphones on.

question: Can I access my Zoom class from a link within Canvas?
human_answer:
No.  Students access their Zoom Gathering from their BYU-Pathway Student Portal.  Students can find the link to their Gathering in their  BYU-Pathway Student Portal (sign in at https://www.byupathway.org,) 

Click "My Gathering" to find the location of your gathering.  The details of your gathering and a link to "Join Virtual Gathering" are included under "My Gathering."

If you are on a mobile device, you can find these options by going to the triple line icon in the top right.
ai_answer:
Yes, you can access your Zoom class from a link within Canvas. To do this, you need to follow these steps:
1. Open your Canvas course and navigate to the specific class where the Zoom link is provided [^3].
2. Look for the Zoom link within the course content or announcements shared by your instructor [^3].
3. Click on the Zoom link provided within Canvas to join your Zoom class directly from the Canvas platform [^3].
4. By accessing your Zoom class through Canvas, you can seamlessly transition between course materials and live class sessions, enhancing your learning experience [^3].

question: What are the duties of mentor?
human_answer:
Mentors focus on providing instructional and developmental support for students at risk which allows them to direct their own path and overcome the challenges they face. They are guides meant to remind students of their purpose, give them the power to succeed, and help them to create a plan that will allow them to continue in BYU-Pathway.  
 
Mentors help students establish and maintain successful habits including time management, study skills, and goal setting. Mentors also help guide students through difficult life circumstances by offering resources and are there to be a supportive, encouraging, and motivating voice throughout their BYU-Pathway educational experience.
ai_answer: Mentors at BYU-Pathway have various duties to support students in their educational journey. They are trained to guide students through their academic and spiritual challenges, offering strategies for success, important reminders, and connecting students to support resources [^1]. Mentors also provide encouragement to help students achieve each milestone on their path to graduation [^1]. Additionally, mentors assist students in establishing and maintaining successful habits such as time management, study skills, and goal setting [^2]. They act as a supportive and motivating voice throughout the BYU-Pathway educational experience, offering guidance during difficult life circumstances and providing resources to help students overcome challenges [^2].

question: What are the duties of an instructor?
human_answer:
The Instructors role is to:
• Shepherd students through the online course to help them know its structure and meet expectations.
• Inspire and motivate students to continue.
• Identify anything that will slow or stop academic success.
• Contact students to provide instruction when needed.
• Help students feel confident in their ability to succeed academically, spiritually, and in life.
ai_answer: Instructors have several key duties in the BYU Pathway program. They are responsible for guiding students through the online course, helping them understand the course structure, and meet its expectations [^3][^4]. Additionally, instructors inspire, motivate, and support students along their academic and spiritual journey [^3][^4]. They identify trends that may impede student success and provide targeted outreach to help students overcome challenges [^3][^4]. Instructors play a crucial role in building capable learners who are confident in their ability to succeed academically, spiritually, and in life [^3][^4]. Furthermore, instructors are expected to respond to student messages within 24 hours, excluding weekends, and address any grievances or concerns promptly [^5]. It is also appropriate for students to contact instructors for support and guidance, as instructors can provide valuable insights based on students' previous work or questions from other students [^6].

The instructor is always present to answer questions or correct any misunderstandings. The students are tasked with creating an assessment that aligns with the course outcomes. Students are also asked to create activities where the rest of the class can actively apply what they are learning. In this way, students are placed at the center of the process.

question: How a tutor can help a student
human_answer: Tutors can provide a supportive environment to address your questions and concerns, help you improve skills, identify areas of improvement, and explain class materials.
ai_answer: A tutor can be a valuable resource for students when they have exhausted their other efforts and need additional support to succeed academically [^1]. Tutors can provide personalized attention to help students understand challenging concepts and improve their performance in specific courses [^2]. By working with a tutor, students can receive guidance and clarification on difficult topics, leading to increased comprehension and better grades [^1]. Additionally, tutors can help students build confidence in their abilities and develop problem-solving skills, ultimately promoting self-reliance and independence in their academic journey [^2].

question: How do students find their canvas the first time?
human_answer: Students find their canvas course for the first time by logging into their Student Portal.  Under "Courses" there is a link to their current or upcoming course.  Note:  Students cannot access their course in Canvas until after the course starts.  The course start date is shown above the course link. Canvas usually opens the Saturday before classes begin.
ai_answer:
To find their Canvas course for the first time, students can follow these steps based on the information provided in the knowledge base:

1. **Access the BYU-Pathway Portal**: Students should log in to the BYU-Pathway Portal using their Church account credentials [^9].
2. **Click on the Course Name**: Once logged in, students need to click on the course name within the portal [^5].
3. **Navigate to the Course Dashboard**: After clicking on the course name, students will be directed to their course dashboard, where they can access course materials and assignments [^2].
4. **Access the Modules Page**: Within the course dashboard, students can navigate to the Modules page, which contains various course items like pages, quizzes, and assignments [^7].
5. **Start Coursework**: Students should read and complete the items in each module from top to bottom to begin their coursework [^7].

Following these steps will help students find their Canvas course for the first time and start engaging with their course materials and assignments effectively.

question: What to do if a member student is being charged friend of the church tuition?
human_answer: The most common reason a member of the Church is charged friend of the Church tuition, is that the student has multiple Church User Accounts and multiple BYU-Pathway Accounts.  Here is how to find if a student has duplicate Pathway Accounts. A student should contact their mentor when they have duplicate accounts.
ai_answer: If a member student is being charged friend of the church tuition, they may need to add their Member Record Number (MRN) to their church account to ensure they are recognized as a member and receive the correct tuition rate [^1]. The PATH system checks for the MRN when a student signs in, and if it finds one, it records the student's ward and stake from their Church record, indicating their membership status [^2]. If the MRN is not linked, the system considers the student a Friend of the Church and charges a higher tuition rate [^2]. Therefore, it is essential for the student to verify and add their MRN to their church account to rectify the tuition issue and pay the correct amount as a member of the church [^1].

question: How do I get instructors to grant extra time to turn in assignments?
human_answer:
A student may need extra time on an assignment due to their current circumstances. Students should contact their instructor.

Students need to work with their instructors for any questions regarding assignments and assignment deadlines. They can communicate with their instructor through the Canvas Inbox.
ai_answer: To get instructors to grant extra time to turn in assignments, you should contact your instructor through the Canvas Inbox [^1]. This is the official communication channel for students to reach out to their instructors regarding coursework-related matters, including requesting extensions [^1]. By using the Canvas Inbox, you can directly communicate your situation and reasons for needing an extension, allowing the instructor to consider your request [^1]. It's important to reach out as soon as you realize you may need extra time to complete an assignment to give the instructor time to review your request and make a decision [^1].

question: How to find the mentor for my gathering?
human_answer: Mentors are assigned to individual students and there could be multiple mentors assigned to students in the same gathering.  The way for missionaries to see what mentors are assigned to their Gathering is to go to the Mentor Group Assignments Page.
ai_answer: To find the mentor for your gathering in BYU-Pathway, there are several ways you can locate this information. One method is to wait for an email from your mentor, which typically occurs between two weeks before courses begin and the start of courses [^2]. Additionally, you can ask your gathering missionary for the mentor's name and contact information [^2]. It's important to note that groups may have more than one mentor assigned to students in the gathering, so reaching out to your gathering missionary for clarification is advisable [^2]. If you have not received communication from your mentor and need assistance, you can also fill out the Mentor Complaints and Grievances form in your student portal [^5].

question: Can a friend of the church become a mentor?
human_answer:
No.  The current qualifications for a Mentor are listed below: 
Must be 18 or older. 
Current Online Degree student 
Member of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints 
Strong English skills
ai_answer: A friend of the church can become a mentor if they meet the specific qualifications set by BYU-Pathway. These qualifications include being 18 years or older, a current online degree student, a member of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, and possessing strong English skills [^2]. The mentor selection process is managed through an agency called Bloom, and individuals who meet the criteria can apply to become mentors through this agency [^2]. If a friend of the church meets these requirements, they can potentially serve as a mentor to BYU-Pathway students.

question: How does a student register for certificate classes?

question: How does a student register for the next PC block?
human_answer:
Students log in to the BYU-Pathway Portal to register. A pop-up menu asks them if they want to register at that time.
If the student responds "no," then a reminder is placed on their personal To-Do list.
ai_answer:
To register for the next PC block, a student needs to follow these steps based on the information provided in the documents:

1. Log in to the BYU-Pathway Portal [^2].
2. Upon logging in, a pop-up menu will ask if the student wants to register at that time [^2].
3. If the student selects "no," a reminder will be placed on their personal To-Do list [^2].
4. Click on **Register For Courses** in the Student Portal [^2].
5. A survey may pop up regarding the student's job or job needs. Answer the questions and click **Submit** [^2].
6. The student will then be directed to the enrollment screen where they can review the course selection and tuition cost [^2].
7. After reviewing, click **Enroll** to complete the registration process [^2].
8. It's important to note that the system may take several minutes to enroll the student after they click **Enroll** [^2].

This is the process a student should follow to register for the next PC block according to the provided information [^2].

question: Is the Hall scholarship different from the Heber J. Grant scholarship?
human_answer:
The Hall Foundation scholarship is different from the Heber J. Grant tuition discount. It is not provided through BYU-Pathway.

ABOUT THE HALL FOUNDATION SCHOLARSHIP

Brad Hall, with his wife Andrea, served as Mission President for The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints in the Mexico City Northwest, Mexico Mission from 2013-2016. While serving, Brad and Andrea had the opportunity to work with hundreds of talented young adults who came from various cultures and backgrounds. They saw many of these young people return to their home countries after their missions where opportunities were scarce, and education was difficult to achieve.

In 2015, the Brad and Andrea Hall Family Foundation was created to offer on-campus scholarships to international returned missionaries from the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.

In 2020, the Hall Foundation Scholarship evolved into a full-tuition, online-only scholarship for returned missionaries to pursue online education through BYU-Idaho or Ensign College.

In 2024, The Hall Foundation extended scholarships to all international online students. Applicants are no longer required to be returned missionaries.
ai_answer: The Hall scholarship and the Heber J. Grant scholarship are different scholarships offered to BYU-Pathway students. The Hall Foundation Scholarship is a full-tuition, online-only scholarship initially designed for returned missionaries but later extended to all international online students, regardless of missionary status [^1]. On the other hand, the Heber J. Grant scholarship is a tuition discount that can be combined with other scholarships but may not exceed a 75% reduction in tuition [^2]. These scholarships have distinct eligibility criteria and benefits, making them separate entities within the BYU-Pathway scholarship offerings.

question: How can we help students financially?
human_answer: To help students financially, there are several ways to provide support based on the resources available through BYU Pathway Worldwide. One option is to assist students in applying for needs-based scholarships. These scholarships are limited to one term during the first year of enrollment and can help cover a portion of the student's tuition costs. Additionally, individuals can donate funds directly to students by following specific guidelines, such as sending a separate check for each student's tuition and ensuring the total amount does not exceed the tuition owed. This direct financial assistance can make a significant difference in helping students meet their educational expenses. Furthermore, students can explore additional financial aid opportunities by searching and applying for private scholarships that align with their needs and qualifications. While federal loans and Pell Grants are not available for degree programs serviced by BYU Pathway in the United States, there are other sources of aid that students can explore to support their financial needs. By leveraging these various avenues of financial assistance, we can effectively support students in their educational pursuits and help alleviate some of the financial burdens they may face.

question: How can a friend who didn't finish PC 103 get back into the course as a returning student?
human_answer: Choose Returning Student Form if the applicant has previously completed one or more terms of BYU-Pathway.This also applies to those who need to retake a term to improve their GPA.
ai_answer:
To help a friend who didn't finish PC 103 get back into the course as a returning student, they will need to follow specific steps outlined in the BYU Pathway program guidelines. Here is a detailed guide based on the available information:

1. **Reapplication Process**: If your friend did not complete PC 103 and wants to rejoin PathwayConnect, they will need to reapply for admission as a returning student [^5]. This means they will need to go through the application process again to be readmitted into the program.

2. **Retaking PC 103**: Since your friend did not finish PC 103, they may need to retake the course to fulfill the program requirements [^6]. PC 103 is essential for developing skills necessary for success as an online student and for preparing for further academic pursuits with BYU Idaho and Ensign College [^6].

3. **Contact BYU-Pathway Support**: It is recommended that your friend contacts BYU-Pathway Support for additional information and details on the reentry process [^5]. They can provide guidance on the specific steps needed to rejoin the program and any additional requirements.

4. **Course Retake Consideration**: Depending on the circumstances of why your friend did not finish PC 103, they may need to consider retaking the course to meet the completion requirements [^2]. Retaking PC 103 can help them strengthen their online learning skills and prepare for future academic endeavors.

In summary, for your friend to get back into PC 103 as a returning student, they will need to reapply for admission, consider retaking the course, contact BYU-Pathway Support for guidance, and ensure they fulfill all necessary requirements for reentry into the PathwayConnect program.

question: What is the Hall scholarship?
human_answer:
ABOUT THE HALL FOUNDATION SCHOLARSHIP

Brad Hall, with his wife Andrea, served as Mission President for The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints in the Mexico City Northwest, Mexico Mission from 2013-2016. While serving, Brad and Andrea had the opportunity to work with hundreds of talented young adults who came from various cultures and backgrounds. They saw many of these young people return to their home countries after their missions where opportunities were scarce, and education was difficult to achieve.

In 2015, the Brad and Andrea Hall Family Foundation was created to offer on-campus scholarships to international returned missionaries from the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.

In 2020, the Hall Foundation Scholarship evolved into a full-tuition, online-only scholarship for returned missionaries to pursue online education through BYU-Idaho or Ensign College.

In 2024, The Hall Foundation extended scholarships to all international online students. Applicants are no longer required to be returned missionaries.
ai_answer: The Hall Foundation Scholarship was established in 2015 by the Brad and Andrea Hall Family Foundation to provide on-campus scholarships to international returned missionaries from The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints [^1]. Initially, the scholarship was created to offer opportunities to young people who returned to their home countries after their missions, where opportunities were scarce and difficult to achieve [^1]. The Hall Foundation Scholarship extended to all international online students who were returned missionaries [^1]. Currently, the Hall Foundation Online Scholarship Application is closed [^1].

question: How does the student get their PC certificate?
human_answer:
Students can print their certificate by doing the following:
Signing into their Student Portal
Selecting the dropdown menu by your name in the right-hand corner
Select “PathwayConnect Certificates” to print off the certificate.
ai_answer: To obtain their PC certificate, the student needs to follow specific steps outlined in the BYU Pathway documents. First, the student must meet the completion requirements before being able to print their certificate [^2]. After meeting these requirements, the student should sign in to their student portal at https://www.byupathway.edu/ [^2]. Then, they should select "PathwayConnect Certificates" from the drop-down menu in the top-right corner of the page [^2]. This selection will allow them to print their certificate of completion directly from the student portal [^2]. The certificate will be available within 24 hours after grades are posted [^5]. Additionally, PathwayConnect Missionaries can assist students in printing their certificates, so students can reach out to their missionary for additional support if needed [^5].

question: How can a student register for the next PC block if they paid tuition late?
human_answer:
A student experiencing financial struggles can submit an exception in order to enroll in the following term.

A student in financial need may request an exception allowing them to register using the Exception Request Form. Their tuition balance will then be rolled into the next term.
 
Students in need of a policy exception for problems with registration due to unpaid tuition, gathering attendance, or language classification should fill out the Exception Request Form. This information submitted will go directly to the enrollment team for review.
 
Only students should fill out and submit this form. You may give the link to students who need an enrollment exception. This form should only be used for policy exceptions, not for general support issues.
ai_answer: To register for the next PC block after paying tuition late, a student can request an exception by filling out the Exception Request Form [^1]. This form allows students in financial need to enroll in the following term despite their late payment [^1]. Once the form is submitted, the tuition balance will be rolled into the next term, and the information will be reviewed by the enrollment team [^1]. Only students should fill out and submit this form, and it should be used specifically for policy exceptions, not general support issues [^1].

question: Can a student receive a refund for their late tuition payment?
human_answer:
A student can request a refund for their late tuition payment through the Exception Request Form.

Students who do not turn in assignments by the drop date will automatically be refunded their tuition payments. Students who continue the course will be charged tuition. Students will be assessed a late fee if they do not pay by the deadline. Students with extenuating circumstances may fill out the exception request form.
ai_answer: Yes, a student can receive a refund for their late tuition payment under certain circumstances. If a student does not pay their full tuition by the Monday of the last week of the semester, they will be assessed a 5% late fee on their remaining balance [^2]. However, students who do not turn in assignments by the drop date will automatically be refunded their tuition payments [^1]. Additionally, students who withdraw on or before the withdrawal deadline of a term will receive a prorated tuition refund [^3]. Students with extenuating circumstances may also fill out an exception request form to address late payment issues [^1].

question: What can a student do if their mentor is not responding?
human_answer: If a student's mentor is not responding, they may submit a concern about their Mentor by going to your Student Portal > Resources > Peer Mentor Problem. They will then be directed to fill out the Mentor Concern Form.
ai_answer: If a student's mentor is not responding, the student can take several steps to address the issue effectively. First, the student should give the mentor 24 hours to respond to their question [^2]. If there is still no response after this period, the student can log in to their BYU-Pathway Portal and submit a concern using the "Mentor Problem?" card under "Resources" [^2]. Additionally, students can fill out the Mentor Concern form found in their student portal to report the lack of response from their mentor [^3]. This form submission will be reviewed by the Mentor team at BYU-Pathway, who will address the situation and potentially assign a new mentor if needed [^6].

question: When can students first log into their canvas Portal?
human_answer:
Access to PathwayConnect courses on Canvas usually opens the Saturday before classes begin. Students trying to access classes before that time you will not have access to Canvas. If a student registers for classes on or after the Saturday before classes begin the student will usually have to wait 24-48 hours for access to their classes. 
 
Students can access their course in Canvas after the course starts.  The course start date is shown above the course link in their Student Portal.

Access PathwayConnect courses by doing the following:
- Login to path.byupathway.org
- In the upper right sid of the Student Portal Home Page, slick the course title of the class.
ai_answer: Students can first log into their Canvas Portal the Saturday before classes begin [^2]. This access allows them to start preparing for their coursework and familiarize themselves with the platform before the term officially starts on Monday [^5]. It is essential for students to log in early to address any login issues and ensure they can begin their coursework on time [^1].

question: How to move a student to another gathering
human_answer:
You should contact your district Leader, zone Leader, or ACM if you have a student who needs to move to a different gathering.

Missionaries who have a student who needs to move to a different gathering should contact their District Leader, Zone Leader, or ACM. Provide your area leader with the following information:
·      ID number
·      Student name
·      Current gathering name
·      Day and time the student or learner needs for the new gathering.
 
Transfer types vary depending on where a student or learner needs to be moved and who is authorized to make the move. A move request will be escalated to the appropriate person(s) that can affect the move.
ai_answer: To move a student to another gathering, you need to follow specific steps based on the situation and location of the student. The process involves contacting the appropriate leaders and providing necessary information for the transfer to take place [^1][^2][^4][^5][^6]. The types of transfers can vary, including moving to a different area, location, or within the same location [^1][^2]. It is essential to escalate the move request to the authorized individuals who can facilitate the transfer [^1][^2]. Students may need to visit another gathering temporarily due to travel or moving, and in such cases, they should coordinate with their gathering group missionaries or instructors [^3]. Additionally, students who require changes in their gathering day or time due to personal circumstances can also request a new gathering time without physically moving [^7].

question: What does the missionary do if a student cannot recover their church account
human_answer:
Students and learners need to communicate with the Global Services Department to resolve all account issues.

·      Direct a student or learner to contact Global Support for help when they cannot log in to their Church account.
·      Log in to the GSD site for a list of support by country (Global Services Department).
·      In the US and Canada call 1-855-537-4357 or locally in the U.S. call 801-240-4357.
ai_answer: If a student cannot recover their Church account, the missionary assigned to PathwayConnect or EnglishConnect 3 should assist in resolving all account issues [^1]. They can guide the student to log in to the Global Services Department (GSD) site for a list of support by country or provide specific contact numbers for support in the US and Canada [^1]. Additionally, missionaries can direct the student to call 1-855-537-4357 or locally in the U.S. call 801-240-4357 for further assistance with account recovery [^1].

question: Can a student get a new mentor?
human_answer:
Students can request a new mentor through the Mentor Concern Form.

Students who have a concern with their mentor can submit a Mentor Concern Form. This submission goes to the Mentor team at BYU-Pathway and will be reviewed. A student may make the request to change mentors in the form submission.
ai_answer: Yes, a student can request a new mentor through the Mentor Concern Form available in the student portal [^1]. When a student submits this form, it is reviewed by the Mentor team at BYU-Pathway, and if approved, the student will be assigned a new mentor [^1]. This process allows students to change mentors if needed to better support their educational journey.

question: How do students find inperson institute classes?
human_answer: If a student is unable to register through the student portal, they may register by using the Institue Class Locator.
ai_answer:
To find in-person Institute classes, students can follow these steps based on the available information:

1. **Navigate to the MyInstitute Page**: Students should log in to their MyInstitute account [^1]. 
2. **Select "Find Classes Near Me"**: Once logged in, students can select the option to find classes near their location [^1].
3. **Choose "In Person" Option**: When selecting a course, students should opt for the "In Person" option to attend classes at a physical church or institute building [^5].
4. **Select Location and Add Course**: After choosing the "In Person" option, students need to select the specific location where they want to attend the class and then click "Add Course" at the bottom of the page [^5].
5. **Verify Registration**: Students should scroll down to verify their course registration day and time to ensure they are successfully enrolled in the in-person Institute class [^5].

By following these steps on the MyInstitute platform, students can easily find and enroll in in-person Institute classes for their academic and spiritual growth.

question: How do students find in-person gatherings?
human_answer: Once a student's enrollment application to PathwayConnect is completed, their application has been accepted and they have accepted their offer, they are given the opportunity to select a gathering.  During that process, the student can choose from either a list of In-Person Gatherings, or Virtual Gatherings.
ai_answer: To find in-person gatherings, students can access the details of their gathering and a link to "Join Virtual Gathering" under "My Gathering" in their PathwayConnect account [^7]. If students do not have this information or need further assistance, they can contact their support missionaries whose contact information is available under "My Contacts" in their PathwayConnect account [^7]. If students still cannot find the information they need, they should reach out to their Peer Mentor for immediate help [^7].

question: How do students contact their instructors?
human_answer: The preferred communication channel for instructors is the Canvas Inbox. Students should check this inbox everytime they log in to Canvas.
ai_answer: Students can contact their instructors through various means, including sending a message through Canvas Inbox, using their personal email (e.g., Yahoo or Gmail), calling or texting the instructor using the provided phone number (if applicable), signing up for office hours via the class portal instructor tab to meet over Zoom, and commenting on the instructor's Announcements [^1]. Additionally, students can communicate with their instructor through the Canvas Inbox for questions regarding assignments and assignment deadlines [^2]. If students encounter issues with instructor responsiveness, they can report problems to a mentor, submit a ticket in the Companion app, file a complaint or grievance against the instructor, or request a Grade Appeals form from the instructor if dealing with graders [^5].

2. Within the tutoring resources tab, students can find information on how to connect with a tutor, including video tutorials on the process [^2].
3. If students feel stuck on an assignment or course and have exhausted other efforts, they are encouraged to contact a tutor for assistance [^3].

question: How do students contact their mentor?
human_answer: Students can get contact information for their mentor by going to their Student Portal, clicking on Support, clicking on Need Help?, and in the chat box, under Popular Topics, clicking on Contact My Mentor.
ai_answer: Students can contact their mentor by following a few simple steps outlined in the BYU-Pathway resources. To reach out to their mentor, students need to sign into the Companion App, click on "My Network," and then choose the "My Mentor" option to connect with their assigned mentor [^4]. Additionally, at the beginning of each term, mentors will introduce themselves to their assigned students, providing an opportunity for initial contact [^4]. Students can also share their preferred contact method with their mentor for future communication [^4].

question: How do students apply to become a mentor?
human_answer:
Mentors are hired through an agency called Bloom. Bloom's hiring processes and decisions are completely separate from BYU-Pathway Worldwide. We are not able to provide insights or timelines on Bloom's hiring processes. 
Students can apply for jobs on Bloom's website, https://hirebloom.com
ai_answer: To apply to become a mentor at BYU-Pathway, students need to meet specific qualifications. These qualifications include being 18 years or older, a current online degree student, a member of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, and possessing strong English skills [^1]. Once these qualifications are met, students can apply to be a mentor by filling out the Mentor Concern form in their student portal [^2]. This form submission will be reviewed by the Mentor team at BYU-Pathway to consider the student's application to become a mentor.

question: How does a student transfer institute credit and previous college credits to BYUI or Ensign College?
human_answer:
For Institute
Students can use the Seminary & Institute app or the MyInstitute website to electronically transfer their Institute credits to a CES school like BYU-Idaho or Ensign College.
 
For Previous College Credit
Students can transfer other college credits in the following ways:
·      Electronically through Parchment Exchange, National Student Clearinghouse, or SCRIP-Safe.
·      Emailed directly from the institution you attended to collegetranscript@byu.edu
·      Mailed directly from the institution you attended to CES Admission Services.
Send to:
​​​​​​​A-41 ASB
Provo, UT 84602
ai_answer:
To transfer institute credit and previous college credits to BYU-Idaho or Ensign College, students have several options based on the information provided in the knowledge base:

1. **Institute Credits to BYU-Idaho:** Students can electronically transfer their Institute credits to BYU-Idaho or Ensign College using the Seminary & Institute app or the MyInstitute website [^1]. They can also have their credits mailed directly from the institution they attended to CES Admission Services at A-41 ASB Provo, UT 84602 [^1].

2. **Transferring College Credits:** For transferring college credits, the process varies depending on the institution and program:
   - **BYU-Idaho Online Degree Program:** Applicants are not required to submit college transcripts from foreign institutions unless they want their credit evaluated for transferability [^2].
   - **BYU-Idaho On-Campus Program:** Applicants are required to submit college transcripts from foreign institutions for credit evaluation [^2].
   - **Ensign College:** The process for transferring college credits to Ensign College is not explicitly mentioned in the provided nodes.

3. **Evaluation of PathwayConnect Credits:** Other colleges or universities, including BYU, BYU-Hawaii, or Ensign College, will evaluate PathwayConnect credits to determine their transferability [^4]. Students interested in transferring to a school other than BYU-Idaho after completing PathwayConnect should contact that specific school to inquire about transfer credit eligibility and evaluation [^4].

4. **Requesting and Sending Transcripts:** For PathwayConnect students applying to BYU-Idaho or Ensign College, transcripts are automatically sent twice: once upon completion of PCB/PCIB 102 and once when accepting an offer to an online degree program [^7]. However, if applying to Ensign College on-campus or BYU-Idaho on-campus, students may need to manually request their transcripts to be sent [^7].

In summary, students can transfer institute credits electronically or by mail and should follow specific procedures for transferring college credits based on the institution and program requirements. It is essential to contact the respective schools for detailed information on credit evaluation and transferability.

question: How does one move from a virtual gathering to a physical gathering?
human_answer:
You may have a student or learner in a virtual gathering that needs to move to an in-person gathering. Your area leaders will help with this process.

You should contact your area leaders (typically a zone or district leader) and provide them with the following student or learner information:
·      ID number
·      Name,
·      Current gathering name,
·      Day and time of the needed gathering
 
Transfer types vary depending on where a student needs to be moved and who is authorized to make the move. A request will be escalated to the appropriate person(s) that can affect the move.
ai_answer: Moving from a virtual gathering to a physical gathering involves a process that varies depending on the student's location and the authorization required for the move. Typically, the student or learner who needs to transition from a virtual to a physical gathering should reach out to their area leaders for assistance in this process [^1]. The request to move will then be escalated to the appropriate person(s) who have the authority to facilitate the transition [^1]. It's essential to provide details such as the current gathering name, the day and time of the needed gathering, and the specific transfer type required for the move [^1]. By following these steps and involving the necessary individuals, students can successfully transition from a virtual to a physical gathering within the BYU Pathway program.

question: What can be done if a student is unable to apply for the Herbert J. Grant tuition discount or register for classes because of technical problems?
human_answer:
Students having technical issues often ask you for help. Students can submit a ticket in their student portal through the chatbot.

Students or learners who are unable to register for courses because of technical issues should submit a ticket or request to meet with an enrollment counselor using the chatbot on the BYU-Pathway homepage.
 
Students who cannot apply for the Heber J. Grant discount because of technical issues should submit a ticket using the chatbot in their student portal. They can also ask their mentor for help to connect with BYU-Pathway Support.
ai_answer: If a student is unable to apply for the Herbert J. Grant tuition discount or register for classes due to technical problems, there are specific steps they can take to address the issue. They should submit a ticket using the chatbot in their student portal [^1]. Additionally, they can meet with an enrollment counselor through the chatbot on the BYU-Pathway homepage for further assistance [^1]. If the technical issues persist, students can also ask their mentor for help to connect with BYU-Pathway Support [^1]. These support channels are available to help students overcome technical obstacles and ensure they can access the necessary resources and benefits for their education.

question: How to resolve a student having two separate PATH entries with different student IDs?
human_answer:
Occasionally, students might create a duplicate Pathway account while applying. This is often due to not applying using their church account where their membership records are attached and instead creating another church account.

To resolve this issue, the student heeds to contact their Mentor to begin the process of merging their duplicate accounts into the account that their membership records are associated.
ai_answer:
To resolve a student having two separate PATH entries with different student IDs, you can follow these steps based on the available information:

1. Check for duplicate accounts by reviewing the student's profile information, including details like Preferred Name, Age, Cell Phone, Email Addresses, Address, Date of Birth, and Gender [^1].
2. Make a note of the Church Account multiple Student IDs to identify the duplicate entries [^1].
3. Once you have identified the duplicate entries, note down the Student IDs associated with each entry.
4. Contact the appropriate support personnel or leadership within the BYU Pathway system to report the issue and request assistance in merging the duplicate accounts [^1].
5. Provide the identified Student IDs for each entry to facilitate the merging process and ensure that the student's information is consolidated into a single PATH entry with a single Student ID [^1].

This is the answer based on the sources [^1].

question: Is there a work around when the student portal says "internal server error" issue when signing into student portal?
human_answer: If a student is unable to get into their student portal, do to software technical errors, they can go to:  http://www.byui.edu/canvas-authentication and login to PathwayConnect Students to access coursework on Canvas directly.
ai_answer:
If a student encounters an "internal server error" issue when trying to sign into the student portal, they can try the following workaround steps based on the information available:

1. Clear the cache in the web browser they are using [^5].
2. Attempt signing in using a different web browser [^5].
3. If the issue persists, the student can have their Academic Service Missionary (ACM) submit a ticket on their behalf [^5].

These steps can help address the "internal server error" problem and allow the student to access the student portal successfully.

question: How can a student change the name on their PathwayConnect certificate?
human_answer: PathwayConnect missionaries can change a student's  name on their PathwayConnect  Completion Certificate when the certificate is being printed. This only changes the Name on the printed Certificate and will not change the student's name in the system. Students should contact their missionary if they would like a different name printed on their certificate.
ai_answer:
To change the name on their PathwayConnect certificate, a student can follow these steps [^2]:

1. Log in to their BYU-Pathway Portal.
2. Click on their name in the top right corner.
3. Click on "PathwayConnect Certificates."
4. The certificate will open with the name and completion year filled in.
5. Submit a ticket in the Companion app in the portal if the information on the certificate is not correct.

By following these steps, students can easily modify the name on their PathwayConnect certificate if needed.

question: Is there an exception request link for online degree students?
human_answer: Students can petition for exceptions.  Petitions may include Academic Ineligibility, Academic Dismissal, or certain graduation requirements. Students can go to Academic Petitions to initiate a petition regarding univertsity policy.
ai_answer: Yes, there is an exception request link available for online degree students who may need to request an exception for specific circumstances related to their enrollment [^1]. This link allows students in financial need to request an exception that would enable them to register for the next term despite having an outstanding tuition balance [^2]. The exception request form is the appropriate channel for students to submit their request, and it will be reviewed by the enrollment team for consideration [^2]. Students should fill out and submit this form only for policy exceptions, not general support issues [^2].

6.6 Other Policies & Procedures / 6.6.3 Exceptions to Policies Students wishing to appeal any policies must submit a petition to BYU-Pathway Support. These situations may include dropping classes, withdrawing from school after published deadlines, or registering for the next semester with outstanding balances. Petitions must be submitted within six months of the semester for which the student is requesting an exception. The petition process is meant to accommodate students with extenuating circumstances or emergencies beyond their control that may impact their academic records. Only BYU-Pathway policies can be appealed; federal guidelines and/or requirements cannot be appealed through this committee.

question: Some of our students would like to know if they have the choice to apply for on-campus degrees at BYU Idaho and Ensign College after BYU PathwayConnect?
human_answer: Yes, Pathway Connect completion students can take on-campus classes at BYUI or Ensign College.
ai_answer: After completing BYU PathwayConnect, students have the option to apply for on-campus degrees at BYU-Idaho and Ensign College [^2]. This opportunity allows students to transition from online learning to experiencing university life on campus and pursuing specific degree programs that may not be available online [^2]. The advising office at BYU-Idaho can assist students in deciding which degree to pursue and provide guidance on the necessary classes for their graduation plan [^2]. Additionally, students enrolled on campus are assigned a faculty mentor who can offer ongoing support throughout their academic journey [^2].

3. Scroll down the Admissions page and click the "Apply Now" button [^3].

By following these steps, students can easily access the BYU-Idaho application to begin their academic journey with BYU-Pathway.

If students do not have a free Microsoft 365 account, they can create one by following specific instructions, which do not require purchasing the software [^3].
