question: How do students change majors? change a certificate course?
human_answer: Students can change/declare their Certificate or Degree in their Degree Planner, found under 'Academic Resources' in their student portal.
ai_answer: To change majors, students can follow a specific process outlined in their Degree Planner within the student portal. They need to access the Degree Planner, select "Change Plan," acknowledge the warning boxes, and then proceed to click on "Change Degree" [^2]. Additionally, students can change their certificate course by accessing the certificate section in their student portal and clicking on "Change." They have the flexibility to switch their certificate choice until the 8th day of PC 103 [^1]. If students need further assistance with changing certificates, they can reach out to BYU-Pathway Support for guidance [^3].

question: How do students obtain their PC certificate? Obtain their major certificates?
human_answer:
Students can print their certificate by doing the following:
Signing into their Student Portal
Selecting the dropdown menu by your name in the right-hand corner
Select “PathwayConnect Certificates” to print off the certificate.
ai_answer:
To obtain their PC certificate, students must meet specific requirements outlined by BYU-Pathway [^6]. These requirements include receiving passing grades in all academic courses within the PathwayConnect program, passing program-required religion or institute courses, achieving a minimum cumulative GPA of 2.0, and having no outstanding PathwayConnect tuition fees [^6].

Once students have met these requirements, they can print their certificate from their student portal [^4]. They need to sign in to the BYU-Pathway website and select "Pathwayconnect Certificates" from the drop-down menu in the top-right corner of the page to access and print their certificate [^4].

Regarding major certificates, students at BYU-Pathway can pursue academic certificates by declaring a bachelor's degree [^2]. They do not need to complete the degree after obtaining the certificate. Students can declare up to three certificates at a time, but it is recommended to pursue only one at a time. The certificates declared must be in the same catalog year, and if a student wants to choose a certificate unrelated to their major, they may need to change their major to Professional Studies to be eligible to select the desired certificate [^2].

question: How am I impacted if I couldn’t get into my Gathering because of technical problems?
human_answer: If students miss gatherings, it will impact their grades. The more gatherings students miss the more impact they will see on their grades.  Students self report gathering attendance.  There may also be assignments relating to the Gathering that the student may be responsible for.  If a student can't get to a Gathering because of technical difficulties, they should report that to their Instructor.
ai_answer:
If you couldn't get into your Gathering due to technical problems, it is essential to address this issue promptly to minimize the impact on your participation and progress in the program. One key step you can take is to contact your Peer Mentor immediately for assistance in resolving the technical issue and accessing your Gathering [^6]. By reaching out to your Peer Mentor, you can receive guidance on troubleshooting the problem and potentially find alternative ways to join the Gathering to ensure you don't miss important information or activities [^6].

Additionally, if you encounter technical difficulties that prevent you from attending your Gathering, it is crucial to communicate this issue to your support missionaries as soon as possible [^4]. Informing them about the situation will help them understand your absence and may allow them to provide you with any necessary information or resources you missed during the Gathering [^4].

In cases where technical problems persist and prevent you from attending multiple Gatherings, it may be necessary to seek further support or accommodations. You can consider submitting a petition to Enrollment Services to request a gathering group waiver due to the ongoing technical challenges you are facing [^2]. By submitting a petition, you can formally request consideration for a waiver that may exempt you from attending a certain number of Gatherings within a term [^2].

Overall, addressing technical issues promptly, seeking assistance from your Peer Mentor and support missionaries, and exploring options like gathering group waivers can help mitigate the impact of technical problems on your participation in Gatherings and your overall experience in the program.

question: How do I get ahold of my mentor?
human_answer: Students can ask their gathering missionary for the mentor's name and contact information.  They can also go to their student portal and slick on Support, then click on Need Help, then in the chat box, go to popular topics and click on Contact my Mentor.
ai_answer:
To get in touch with your mentor at BYU-Pathway, you can follow these steps:
1. Sign into the Companion App.
2. Click on "My Network."
3. Choose the "My Mentor" option to connect with your mentor [^1].
4. If you need your mentor's contact information, you can ask the chat "Who is my mentor?" in the BYU-Pathway Guide [^2].
5. If you ever need to contact your mentor but cannot reach them, you can click on the "Need help?" button in the student portal and ask, "Who is my mentor?" to get their contact information [^3].

question: When can I get into Canvas?
human_answer:
Access to PathwayConnect courses on Canvas usually opens the Saturday before classes begin. Students trying to access classes before that time you will not have access to Canvas. If a student registers for classes on or after the Saturday before classes begin the student will usually have to wait 24-48 hours for access to their classes. 
 
Students can access their course in Canvas after the course starts.  The course start date is shown above the course link in their Student Portal.

Access PathwayConnect courses by doing the following:
- Login to path.byupathway.org
- In the upper right sid of the Student Portal Home Page, slick the course title of the class.
ai_answer: Access to Canvas for PathwayConnect courses usually opens the Saturday before classes begin [^2]. If you are new and trying to access classes before that time, you will not have access to Canvas [^2]. Students who register and have classes on or after the Saturday before classes begin will usually have to wait 24-48 hours for access to their classes [^2]. To access your PathwayConnect courses on Canvas, you can log in to path.byupathway.org, click "Current" on the right side of the page, and then click the course title of the class [^2]. Following these steps will redirect you to your PathwayConnect Canvas where you can access your coursework [^2].

question: I am having issues with Canvas connections, how do I get ahold of someone to chat with to help me resolve those questions.
human_answer:
Troubleshooting Steps
Some Canvas issues can be solved by doing the following:
Switching web browsers. The recommended browsers are, in the best order: 
Google Chrome
Microsoft Edge - updated version
Mozilla Firefox
Clearing cookies and history (see this tutorial: How to Clear Cache and Cookies)
Removing/disabling pop-up blockers
Accessing Canvas through the direct link: BYU-Pathway Canvas Login
Using a laptop or desktop computer. (Tablets, Chromebooks, and I-pads often don't have the necessary plug-ins or system requirements to properly access Canvas courses) 
Making sure that any internet filters on your browsers are turned off for Canvas so assignments can be downloaded
Contacting your instructor for the following reasons:
If you are having issues with the textbook (if applicable)
To see if the student has limited student access to certain assignments or has not posted certain assignments yet

If a student needs an assignment reopened or would like a due date extended, they should contact the instructor and explain the situation with an understanding that the instructor may or may not reopen the assignment. Any questions regarding assignments (access, broken link, due dates) should be directed to the instructor.
ai_answer:
To get assistance with your Canvas connection issues, you can contact your instructor through the Canvas Inbox feature. Here's how you can do it:
1. Log in to Canvas and locate the Inbox feature [^2].
2. Select the option to compose a new message [^2].
3. Choose the course related to your issue from the dropdown menu [^2].
4. Click on the address book to select your instructor from the list [^2].
5. Write your message detailing the Canvas connection problems you are experiencing [^2].
6. You can also mark the conversation as read or unread and star conversations for easy reference [^2].

By following these steps and reaching out to your instructor via the Canvas Inbox, you can get the help you need to resolve your Canvas connection issues [^2].

question: How can I have my assignment due date extended if I have technical problems?
human_answer:
A student having technical problems need to request an assignment due date extension to their instructor using the Canvas Inbox.

Students should address all questions regarding their coursework to their instructors. Instructors are the ones that can approve any homework due date extensions.
Students should contact their instructors for assistance if they have a situation in which they need to submit work later than the due date because of technical issues. Instructors will inform students of their options and the specific consequences of late work.

It's essential to communicate with your instructor promptly and explain your situation to request an extension [^2].

question: How can I give missionaries or a BOM to friends of the church?
human_answer:
How to Download the Book of Mormon App

While most church members are used to reading the Book of Mormon on the Gospel Library app, the Book of Mormon app is much less overwhelming for a first-time reader. Users can read and listen to the Book of Mormon in over 100 languages, chat with a missionary, and discover additional resources.

Share for iOS
Share for Android
Share via Missionaries

For your friends, family, neighbors, workplace acquaintances other people you know, introducing them to the Book of Mormon yourself will be most meaningful. But in some cases—such as an interaction with a stranger in an online forum—it may feel appropriate to share this page with them so that they can receive the Book of Mormon from missionaries:

Request a Book of Mormon from Missionaries

Asking a friend to meet with the missionaries is a powerful way to share the light of the gospel of Jesus Christ. You want your friend to have a positive experience with the missionaries as they discover, learn, and grow. Now you can be more involved to help that happen. When you refer a friend to the missionaries, you can help the missionaries understand your friend’s needs, interests, and questions. You can also join the gospel discussions or missionary lessons in person or online. Do not just tell the missionaries to “drop by” on a friend without asking them.
ai_answer:
To give missionaries or a Book of Mormon (BOM) to friends of the church, you can follow these steps based on the available information:

1. **Share the Book of Mormon**: You can invite someone to watch a Book of Mormon video, read an illustrated Book of Mormon story, or send them the Book of Mormon app in their native language [^3]. Sharing how the Book of Mormon answers questions of the soul can be impactful.

2. **Help a Friend Connect with Missionaries**: Referring a friend to the missionaries is a powerful way to share the light of the gospel of Jesus Christ [^2]. By helping the missionaries understand your friend's needs, interests, and questions, you can facilitate a positive experience for your friend as they discover, learn, and grow in their faith journey.

3. **Explain Gospel Resources**: As part of your role, ensure that students who are friends of the Church and members do not feel excluded [^5]. You can help them understand core beliefs, find a local Church to visit, and become familiar with the Gospel Library and how to download the mobile app, including providing them with a physical copy of the Book of Mormon if possible.

By combining these approaches, you can effectively give missionaries or a Book of Mormon to friends of the church, supporting them in their spiritual journey and helping them connect with valuable gospel resources [^3] [^2] [^5].

question: What scholarships are available?
human_answer: Heber J Grant scholarship;  Return Missionary Scholarship; Ivory Funds Scholarship; All   scholarships are available for PathwayConnect students.
ai_answer: There are several scholarships available for BYU-Pathway students. One of the scholarships is the Heber J. Grant Scholarship, which guarantees all students a scholarship that can cover up to 75% of tuition costs [^1]. Additionally, there is the Returned Missionary Scholarship, and for students living in Eastern regions, there is the Ivory Funds Scholarship [^1]. Students who complete PathwayConnect and continue to pursue online certificates and degrees may reapply for the Heber J. Grant Scholarship [^1]. Furthermore, students in the United States may also be eligible for U.S. federal financial aid when pursuing online certificates and degrees [^1]. Private scholarships are also available for students to search and apply for based on their individual needs and qualifications [^3][^4].

question: Is there any financial assistance for students who can't pay tuition?
human_answer: Needs based discounts are also available for students who are working with a mentor.
ai_answer: Financial assistance is available for students who are unable to pay their tuition at BYU Pathway. One option for financial assistance is the Heber J. Grant Tuition Discount, which is a needs-based discount that can range from 10% to 50% of tuition costs [^6]. Additionally, students may be eligible for private scholarships that fit their individual needs and qualifications [^5]. In cases of extenuating circumstances preventing students from paying their tuition, they can potentially petition for a tuition waiver [^1]. Students in financial need may also request an exception to allow them to register for the next term even if their current term's tuition has not been paid in full [^3].

question: Does BYU advertise online student jobs?
human_answer: BYU-Pathway’s Career Center can help you prepare for and find a job, network, and get you on a path to a great career.
ai_answer: BYU does advertise online student jobs through BYU-Pathway. BYU-Pathway provides access to job opportunities for students enrolled in online degree programs at partner schools like BYU-Idaho and Ensign College [^2]. These job opportunities are available in various regions, including Africa, Asia/Pacific, Europe, Latin/Central America, and South America, and students can access job alerts and links to apply for these positions [^2].

question: What opportunities are available to work for BYU (both member or friend of the church)?
human_answer: Find current Employment and Job opportunities with BYU-Pathway
ai_answer: BYU offers various opportunities for individuals, both members and friends of the Church, to work and contribute to its mission. One such opportunity is through becoming a remote online adjunct instructor hired through BYU-Idaho. These instructors have the chance to share their professional expertise while also offering a testimony and gospel perspective to students [^1]. Additionally, BYU provides employment opportunities through its partner schools within the Church Educational System (CES), including faculty, staff, and administrative positions where individuals can use their talents to contribute to the unique spirit and mission of these institutions [^1]. If you are interested in teaching and sharing your knowledge with students, these opportunities could be a great fit for you.

1. Be written for the exact amount of your tuition that the donating party would like to pay – full/partial for one semester. (The total check amount cannot exceed the amount of tuition currently owed.)
2. Include your name and PathwayConnect ID on the check
3. Include a note with the email address to send the payment receipt
4. Send separate checks for each student’s tuition if donating to multiple students
5. Must be a domestic check
 
Checks can take up to 1 week to be processed once they are received. Enrollment will waive the late fee if the check arrives after the tuition deadline.

question: What if a student is unable to attend their Gathering and needs to visit another Gathering at another time or location that week?
human_answer:
Students who are traveling and are unable to attend their assigned gathering(s) may attend another gathering and still obtain attendance credit.

Students attending a physical gathering may visit a virtual gathering. Those attending a virtual gathering may attend a physical gathering

Students must attend a gathering that coincides with the course in which they are enrolled: 101, 102 or 103. (This does not apply to institute courses.)

Each time a visit is made, it needs to be arranged for by the student's gathering missionaries.
ai_answer: If a student is unable to attend their Gathering and needs to visit another Gathering at another time or location that week, they should plan the visit through their gathering group missionaries [^1]. The student's gathering missionaries need to arrange the visit to another gathering for the student [^1]. It is essential for the student to communicate with their gathering group leaders to ensure a smooth transition to the alternative gathering [^1].

question: Why do we Gather?
human_answer:
There is something about lifting and building others that is foundational to why we gather. One of the miracles of BYU-Pathway is in the gathering. Think about all of the learning opportunities tied to the gatherings.

No doubt about it, gatherings are key to student success!
ai_answer: Gathering is essential because it allows students to learn, prepare for opportunities and responsibilities, strengthen each other, develop relationships, and create eternal families [^3]. It provides a sense of assurance, encouragement, and a purpose greater than oneself [^3]. Additionally, gathering helps individuals increase their understanding of the purpose and measure of their creation [^3]. The Learning Model, which includes teaching one another, relies on gathering as it is challenging to teach without others present in the course [^1].

question: What to do after the gathering
human_answer:
Remind lead and observing students to remain after the meeting for the Lead Student
Feedback Session.

Invite the lead student and the observing student to a breakout room.
• Conduct the Lead Student Feedback Session.
• When the session is complete, exit the breakout room.
• Stay and chat with the students until they leave or exit the Zoom room. Consider leaving your room open for students to chat.
ai_answer: After the gathering, missionaries should engage in various activities to support the students and ensure a successful session. They should answer any questions about BYU-Pathway that students may have [^3]. Additionally, they can ask the lead and observing students to assist in answering questions if possible [^3]. Missionaries should also offer to help guests fill out the application for the next term [^3]. Furthermore, missionaries should conduct a feedback session with the lead and observing students, reviewing the completed Observation and Feedback Sheet, highlighting positive points, offering suggestions for improvement if prompted by the Spirit, and closing the session with feelings of love and encouragement [^3]. This feedback session can be held at another time or over a preferred communication channel if needed [^3].

question: As a new student, can I enroll in the 120-Credit program after 2024?
human_answer: No, all programs provided by BYU-Pathway Worldwide will be the three-year (90-96 credit) bachelor’s degrees after 2024.
ai_answer: As a new student, you will not be able to enroll in the 120-Credit program after 2024. Instead, all programs offered by BYU-Idaho and Ensign College will be the three-year (90-96 credit) bachelor’s degrees after 2024 [^1]. This change is part of the transition to the new three-year degree structure, which will be the standard for all new students starting in Spring Semester 2024 [^1]. Therefore, as a new student, you will be eligible for the three-year bachelor’s degrees offered by these institutions, which are designed to be completed in a shorter timeframe with fewer credits required [^8].
